ticket.title: ActiveResource should use to_param to generate routes
ticket.original-body:
Let's say you have a resource that uses a permalink to_param, instead of id.
To find this using ActiveResource, you'd usually do something like:
@@@ ruby ar = MyActiveResource.new :id => 'my-permalink' ar.id #=> 'my-permalink'
ar.get(:custom_action) ar.id #=> 5 @@@
However, this causes problems for the next call you do to 'ar', because id will be over-written by the ID of the object, not the permalink.
If you did a subsequent call again (or a save), you'd get a 404, because you're actually sending the ID, not the permalink.
@@@ ruby ar.get(:custom_action) ar.save @@@
Instead, the solution should be to let you set a to_param method in your ActiveRecord class that can be overridden in 'permalink'-style cases. E.g.:
@@@ ruby MyActiveResource < ActiveResource::Base def to_param self.permalink end end @@@
So the following would work:
@@@ ruby ar = MyActiveResource.new :permalink => 'my-permalink' ar.id #=> nil ar.permalink #=> 'my-permalink' ar.to_param #=> 'my-permalink'
ar.get(:custom_action) ar.id #=> 5 ar.permalink #=> 'my-permalink' ar.to_param #=> 'my-permalink'
ar.get(:custom_action) # now works! ar.save # now works! @@@
Any thoughts appreciated before I dive in and take the time to submit the patch!

ar.get(:custom_action) # now works! ar.save # now works! @@@

ticket.original-body-html:
Let's say you have a resource that uses a permalink to_param, instead of id.

To find this using ActiveResource, you'd usually do something like:


ar = MyActiveResource.new :id => 'my-permalink'  
ar.id                            #=> 'my-permalink'

ar.get(:custom_action)
ar.id                            #=> 5

However, this causes problems for the next call you do to 'ar', because id will be over-written by the ID of the object, not the permalink.

If you did a subsequent call again (or a save), you'd get a 404, because you're actually sending the ID, not the permalink.


ar.get(:custom_action)
ar.save

Instead, the solution should be to let you set a to_param method in your ActiveRecord class that can be overridden in 'permalink'-style cases. E.g.:


MyActiveResource < ActiveResource::Base
  def to_param
    self.permalink
  end
end

So the following would work:


ar = MyActiveResource.new :permalink => 'my-permalink'  
ar.id                                        #=> nil
ar.permalink                            #=> 'my-permalink'
ar.to_param                             #=> 'my-permalink'

ar.get(:custom_action)
ar.id                                        #=> 5
ar.permalink                            #=> 'my-permalink'
ar.to_param                             #=> 'my-permalink'

ar.get(:custom_action)  # now works!
ar.save    # now works!

Any thoughts appreciated before I dive in and take the time to submit the patch!

Let's say you have a resource that uses a permalink to_param, instead of id.

To find this using ActiveResource, you'd usually do something like:


ar = MyActiveResource.new :id => 'my-permalink'  
ar.id                            #=> 'my-permalink'

ar.get(:custom_action)
ar.id                            #=> 5

However, this causes problems for the next call you do to 'ar', because id will be over-written by the ID of the object, not the permalink.

If you did a subsequent call again (or a save), you'd get a 404, because you're actually sending the ID, not the permalink.


ar.get(:custom_action)
ar.save

Instead, the solution should be to let you set a to_param method in your ActiveRecord class that can be overridden in 'permalink'-style cases. E.g.:


MyActiveResource < ActiveResource::Base
  def to_param
    self.permalink

end

So the following would work:


ar = MyActiveResource.new :permalink => 'my-permalink'  
ar.id                                        #=> nil
ar.permalink                            #=> 'my-permalink'
ar.to_param                             #=> 'my-permalink'

ar.get(:custom_action)
ar.id                                        #=> 5
ar.permalink                            #=> 'my-permalink'
ar.to_param                             #=> 'my-permalink'

ar.get(:custom_action)  # now works!
ar.save    # now works!

Any thoughts appreciated before I dive in and take the time to submit the patch!
version.title: ActiveResource should use to_param to generate routes

version.body: This actually only applies to ActiveResource::CustomMethods ActiveResource already uses to_param
version.body-html: This actually only applies to ActiveResource::CustomMethods ActiveResource already uses to_param
version.title: ActiveResource should use to_param to generate routes

version.body: Here's two patches, apply to_param first then to_param2 after. The second patch removes some debug stuff. The third patch applies to Rails 3.
version.body-html: Here's two patches, apply to_param first then to_param2 after. The second patch removes some debug stuff. The third patch applies to Rails 3.

version.body:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least three months.
The resources of the Rails core team are limited, and so we are asking for your help. If you can still reproduce this error on the 3-0-stable branch or on master, please reply with all of the information you have about it and add "[state:open]" to your comment. This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.
Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
version.body-html:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least three months.

The resources of the Rails core team are limited, and so we are asking for your help. If you can still reproduce this error on the 3-0-stable branch or on master, please reply with all of the information you have about it and add "[state:open]" to your comment. This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.

Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
